In 2017, Your Money Matters followers took part in the #52weekmoneychallenge.
During the first week, they put aside a dollar. Week two, two dollars. Week three, three dollars. Spot the trend? By the end of 2017, they should have saved $1,378! 
We’d like to find out if you were able to commit to this new money-saving habit. Did making a plan help you reach your savings goal? Let us know in the comment box below.
Will you pledge to take the 52-week money challenge in 2018? 
More saving tips: 
http://ow.ly/DOIh30hs54I

caption_original:
DYK your child could get up to $7,200 from the Government of Canada to help pay for his or her education after high school?

Through the Canada Education Savings Grant, the Government adds money to your child’s Registered Education Savings Plan (RESP) to help his or her savings grow. To be eligible for the grant, you must start to save for your child’s #RESP before the end of the calendar year in which he or she turns 15 years of age. 

Find out how to apply: http://ow.ly/JLNo30gX4Pe

To be eligible for the grant, you must start to save for your child’s before the end of the calendar year in which he or she turns years of age. Find out how to apply:

Holiday shopping online this year? 

If you get an email claiming to be from a bank or company asking you to confirm your holiday purchase by providing your credit card number, don’t do it! Reputable firms don’t ask for your personal info via email. 

Learn more about Internet threats related to spam: http://ow.ly/Kv2a30gX5nf

Colder nights mean colder starts to your morning drive.

Use a block heater on a timer for 2 hours before you start your car’s engine to save on fuel costs and consumption.

Learn more about warming your engine without breaking the bank: http://ow.ly/qnca30h6xrn

caption_original:
Renters: DYK your landlord is responsible for respecting the minimum temperature for rental housing set by the municipality you live in?

If your landlord is not meeting the minimum, you can file a complaint with your city’s building and inspections department or your city councillor.

Know your rights as a tenant. Check the fact sheet for your province or territory to learn more: http://ow.ly/wmxs30gX3eS

Buying your sugar, flour and chocolate chips in bulk for your holiday cookie baking?

Do you use public Wi-Fi to catch up on social media?
Using public Wi-Fi may be convenient, but it can be risky. If you must do something online that involves your personal information, it’s safer to use your wireless data plan than an unsecured network.
For more #WiseFi tips, check out: http://ow.ly/YPCR30hs3ME

caption_original:
Getting ready to deck your home with some festive decorations? 

If your plan includes lights, be sure to start with ENERGY STAR–certified LED light strings. Since they use 75% less energy than conventional incandescent lights, you’ll save on your energy bill while giving your home that festive glow. Plus, these lights last up to 10 times longer, so you’ll continue to save by needing fewer replacement bulbs.  

Get helpful tips: http://ow.ly/Mv0B30gX3SQ

Don’t forget to put out the fire before Santa comes down the chimney! 

And if you’re buying firewood, make sure it’s sold on the basis of a legal unit of measurement such as a stacked cubic metre. Be present at delivery and get a receipt, then neatly stack and measure your unloaded firewood.

The holiday season can be expensive – make sure you #getwhatyoupayfor when buying firewood.
http://ow.ly/WrQ030hfWdr

Canada’s anti-spam legislation prohibits anyone from installing software—including updates—on your electronic devices without your consent. 

It also applies to updates and upgrades installed by somebody else, even if you installed the original software. If you think someone has installed malicious software or has modified your software in a harmful way, report it at http://ow.ly/RfHE30hfYvt #FightSpam

caption_original:
It’s officially winter!

And if your winter plans include a vacation or extended stay away from home, be sure to unplug whatever isn’t essential to save on your electricity bill. 

Standby power consumption can account for 5 to 10 % of a household’s electricity costs.

Learn more about ways to save power and money: http://ow.ly/3NuJ30hfXBs

Even though a #paydayloan might seem like an easy fix, you could be in for a shock on payday. 

If you can’t pay the loan back right away, the interest will balloon. Learn more about other options—like cashing in vacation days or taking a cash advance on a credit card—before getting a payday loan: http://ow.ly/wHWh30gNs6U #FLM2017

caption_original:
A consumer proposal is a plan to pay your creditors a percentage of what is owed to them or to extend the time you have to pay off your debts, or both. 
Learn more about consumer proposals: http://ow.ly/Lmqg30hs4Is #consumerproposal

Shopping for great #BoxingDay deals on electronics, home appliances or big-ticket items?

Before paying for an extended warranty, read it carefully to find out what is and isn’t covered. 

Check to see if the product you’re buying comes with a manufacturer’s warranty. Also check if your credit card company offers additional warranties on products paid with a credit card. You may already be covered!

More information on extended warranties: http://ow.ly/xUAu30hoMZZ

Consumed by debt?

Check your home for gaps and cracks that let in the cold and cause your heating system to work harder. Sealing and insulating can make your home more comfortable and save you money on your energy bill.
